questionListItems.title: What is an Institution of a Public Character (IPC) status?

answer.body:
IPC is a status accorded to a registered charity or an exempt charity for a period of time. In addition to the income tax and property tax benefits enjoyed by registered charities, IPCs are authorised to issue tax deduction receipts for qualifying donations received.


IPCs are required to conduct activities that exclusively benefit the local community and are not confined to sectional interests or groups of persons based on race, belief or religion. This means that IPCs are not allowed to conduct overseas activities that benefit the overseas community.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: What are the benefits of having an IPC status?

answer.body:
Charities with IPC status are able to issue tax-deduction receipts for qualifying donations received from donors. In other words, donors are given tax deduction for qualifying donations made to an IPC.

 

Currently, donors are given a tax deduction of 2.5 times for the donations made to IPC.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: What are the criteria to qualify for IPC status application?

answer.body:
The criteria includes:

a)     It is a registered charity or an exempt charity in Singapore;

b)     Its governing instruments are approved by the Sector Administrator;

c)     Its activities exclusively benefit the community in Singapore as a whole and are not confined to sectional interests or group of persons based on race,  belief or religion. 

d)     Its activities meet the IPC's objectives under its governing instruments and the objectives of its Sector Administrator;

e)     The governing board fulfils the independence requirement in Regulation 3(4) of the Charities (Institutions of A Public Character) Regulations;

f)      At least half of the governing board members are Singapore Citizens;

g)     Its governing board members are accountable for the management of donations received; and

h)     Its auditor is approved by the Sector Administrator.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Can an organisation apply for IPC status without/before registering as a charity?

answer.body: No. An organisation will have to be an existing registered charity before it can qualify to apply for IPC status. Hence, if the organisation is not an existing registered charity, the organisation will first need to submit a charity application and obtain charity status before it can qualify for an IPC application.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Once an organisation obtained an approved charity status, can the organisation apply for IPC status immediately?

answer.body: Generally, the charity’s track records (e.g. on its charitable activities, financial position) may be taken into consideration when assessing the IPC application, hence we recommend charities to run the operations for at least two years before submitting an application for IPC status.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: What are the supporting documents required when submitting an IPC application?

answer.body:
Please provide the following supporting documents when submitting the IPC application on the Charity Portal:

a)     Past and Planned Activities for the past 2 years and next 2 years;

b)     Donations received in the past 2 years and target donation amount for the next 2 years; and

c)     Annual expenditure in the past 2 years and estimated expenditure amount for the next 2 years.

 

As it is an existing charity, the following documents should also be available on the Charity Portal:   

a)     Latest copy of the Governing Instrument;

b)     Governance Evaluation Checklists and Annual Submissions i.e. Financial Statements and Annual Reports for the last 5 years;

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Does IPC status have a validity period?

answer.body: Yes. The COC or SA will assess the IPC application and grant a validity period (on a case-by-case basis). IPCs may apply for its approval as an IPC to be extended upon expiry of its validity period, where the application will be reviewed accordingly.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: How long is the estimated processing timeline of the IPC application?

answer.body: The estimated processing timeline to process an “Application for Approval as an IPC” are 90 days from the day the application is submitted; subjected to completeness of application.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: When should an IPC submit an Application for Extension as an IPC?

answer.body:
The Application for Extension as an IPC will be available 4 months before the expiry of the current approval.

 

As the estimated processing timeline is 60 days from the day the application is submitted; subject to completeness of application, we suggest the application for extension as an IPC be submitted at the earliest possible date so that there is ample time for both the charity and the COC/SA to act should further clarification be required.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: An IPC intends to prepare for IPC extension application. However, the link to the Application for Extension as an IPC on Charity Portal is not clickable.

answer.body:
The link to submit an Application for Extension as an Institution of a Public Character (IPC) will only be available for access on the Charity Portal 4 months before the expiry date.

 

That said, IPCs may download an offline copy of the application form to prepare for the submission. The form is available on the Charity Portal >> Institution of a Public Character (IPCs) >> About IPCs

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: How do the general public obtain the list of registered charities and IPCs in Singapore?

answer.body:
1. Perform an Advanced Search on the Charity Portal;

  2. Select and enter the search criteria to filter and proceed to click “Search”;

  3. To narrow down the search results, click on “Filter” to apply additional filters;

  4. Select additional filters and click “Apply”, the results will be generated which you can export into an excel file.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: What types of donations to IPCs are eligible for tax deduction?

answer.body:
The following types of donations are tax deductible when donated to an IPC:

  • Cash Donations

  • Shares Donations

  • Artefact Donations

  • Public Art Tax Incentive Scheme

  • Land and Building Donations

 

For donations other than cash, donors may be required to apply to relevant government agencies to assess the value of donation.

 

***For more information, please visit IRAS at www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/other-taxes/charities/donations-tax-deductions.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: What are the types of non-tax deductible donations?

answer.body:
These donations are not tax deductible:

 

  1. Donations where the donor is essentially advertising at the IPC facility, event or programme. Donors displaying their banners, product or other collaterals at the IPC facility, event or programme to which it has donated is regarded as advertising or marketing expenses and not a donation; and

  2. Donations or gifts that are for a foreign charitable purpose (e.g. donations made to some overseas relief funds managed by an approved IPC).

 

***For more information, please visit IRAS at www.iras.gov.sg/taxes/other-taxes/charities/donations-tax-deductions.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Is donation of computers tax deductible?

answer.body: The tax deduction scheme for donation of computers has been withdrawn with effect from 21 Feb 2017. A company that donates computers to prescribed education, research, or other institution in Singapore and IPC on or after 21 Feb would not be eligible for any tax deduction. Companies that donated computers (include computer hardware, software, accessories and peripherals such as monitors, printers and scanners) before 21 Feb 2017 would continue to enjoy the 250% tax deduction, subject to certain conditions.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: How much tax benefit do donors receive from qualifying donations made to IPCs?

answer.body:
To continue encouraging Singaporeans to give back to the community and to provide strong support for the charity sector, the Minister for Finance has announced in Budget 2021 that the 250% tax deduction for qualifying donations will be extended for another two years till 31 December 2023.

 

For the latest information regarding the Amount of Tax Deduction, please refer to IRAS’s website

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status
